field_edited_text.value:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route



Significant or Important Properties

The Northern Route would involve the acquisition of 6 churches as
follows:

Orchard Street Methodist Episcopal Church—>510 Orchard Street

New Jerusalem Church—Calvert & Chase Streets

Mt. Sinai Baptist Church—922 East Preston Street

Memorial Baptist Church—1301 North Caroline Street

Southern Baptist Church—Bond & Preston Streets

Israel Baptist Church—1230 North Chester Street

While there are some churches of the store front variety along the
Harbor Route there are no regular church buildings.

The Northern Route would take the Richmond Market building as
well as the small group of remodeled dwellings along Tyson Street.

To ascertain which other buildings on both routes might be of some
consequence, buildings having an improvement assessment of $50,000 or
more were sorted out. Table 5 lists those buildings in this category on
the Northern Route; Table 6 shows similar buildings on the Harbor Route.

Of the six buildings on the Northern Route assessed at $50,000 or
over, all give the impression of being relatively new and in good shape.
Even the apartment house at 1001 St. Paul Street, which goes back to
1927, appears relatively modern. The highest assessment, $840,000, be-
longs to 1010 St. Paul Street, an apartment house less than 10 years old.
This assessment is more than three times the next largest assessment on
either route.

On the Harbor Route there are twelve buildings assessed at $50,000
or over, or twice as many as on the Northern Route. For the most part,
however, these buildings give the impression of being old and obsolete.
Two are wholly vacant warehouses. It is understood that the Joseph M.
Zamoiski Company is building a new warehouse and it is therefore as-

56

sumed that the very large but ancient building which this firm now
occupies will also be vacant fairly soon.
From an exterior inspection there are only four buildings on the
Harbor Route which appear to be of real significance:
a. The Hutzler warehouse at 719-725 West Lombard Street. A
fairly old building but large and apparently in good condition.
b. The old Sharp and Dohme plant in the 300 block of West Pratt
Street which is now in dual ownership. One portion, 309-317
West Pratt Street, is presently occupied by Stewart’s warehouse
and has an improvement assessment of $50,000. The other por-
tion, 319-321 West Pratt Street, is occupied by John C. Stalfort
& Sons, Inc., manufacturing chemists. The Stalfort portion has
an improvement assessment of $40,000. The combined building
is a fairly substantial six-story structure. Its exact age is un-
known, but it would appear to be about forty years old.

TABLE 5

PROPERTIES WITH IMPROVEMENT ASSESSMENTS OVER
$50,000 NORTHERN ROUTE - MYRTLE AVENUE
TO NORTHEAST EXPRESSWAY

Improvement
Address Assessment Remarks
237-245 West Biddle Street $ 79,300 General Vending Sales Corp.

1010 St. Paul Street 840,000 Large modern apartment house
1001 St. Paul Street 271,000 Large modern apartment house
1020 North Linwood Avenue 56,800 Telephone Building

810-814 North Haven Street 51,500 Paturzo Concrete Block Plant
4209 East Chase Street 86,400 Bruning Paint Company
